fields.description:
When a new repository is added, it inherits default repository settings. One can disable that immediately after adding that repo, but there is a gap between adding a repo and making it secret.
There should be a way to set repository permissions directly in the "add repository" dialog, or at least by default restrict the access level to none.

h5.Workaround
Add repository as disabled, then only its name will leak.
fields.summary: Allow setting repository permissions on the add repository dialog

fields.description:
h3. Summary
After upgrading to FishEye 4.+, the email field is empty in the user details for users that are imported from an [External user directory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/External+user+directories].

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Using a FishEye version prior to 4 (e.g. 3.9)
## Create a user in FishEye and provide a user name and an email address
## Connect FishEye to an external user directory leaving the "Email attribute" setting empty containing a user name matching the one crated in the above step
## The user will not be linked to LDAP (see Type field) and the email attribute is still present:
## !FE6581_user_beforeUpgrade.png|width=200px!
# Upgrade to FishEye version 4.+

h3. Expected Results
The email address field is preserved.

h3. Actual Results
The email address field is empty.
!FE6581_user_afterUpgrade.png|width=200px!

h3. Notes
This may have an impact when detecting the author of a commit.
For example, the fecru_test4 user has been used to perform a commit to a repository (this is a Git commit with fecru_test4 name and fecru_test4@atlassian.com email).

With FishEye 3.9 the commit is correctly associated with the user:
!FE6581_commitHistory_beforeUpgrade.png|width=200px!

After the upgrade to FIshEye 4.0 the commit is not associated to the user anymore:
!FE6581_commitHistory_afterUpgrade.png|width=200px!
fields.summary: After upgrading to FishEye 4.+, the email field is empty in the user details

fields.description:
FishEye Version:4.0.3 Build:20160323115009 2016-03-23

h2. Setup
* Admin --> Repository Settings --> Defaults --> Tarballs
** Allow users to download repository trees as tarballs: No
* Admin --> Repository Settings --> Repositories --> Native repository access --> <myRepo> --> Tarballs
** Use the system default settings for tarballs: No
** Allow users to download repository trees as tarballs: Yes
** No more than: 100 files

h2. Expected
* "Download" link to be shown when viewing repository files.

h2. Result
* No "Download" link anywhere to be found.
----

h2. Setup
* Admin --> Repository Settings --> Defaults --> Tarballs
** Allow users to download repository trees as tarballs: Yes
** No more than: 10 files 
* Admin --> Repository Settings --> Repositories --> Native repository access --> <myRepo> --> Tarballs
** Use the system default settings for tarballs: No
** Allow users to download repository trees as tarballs: Yes
** No more than: 100 files

h2. Expected
* Ability to download 100 files for <myRepo>.

h2. Result
* "Download" only grabs 10 files (system defaults).
----

{panel}
So it looks like only the global configuration is being used, not the repository specific settings.
{panel}
fields.summary: FishEye tarball settings not respected per repository

fields.description:
When I have a group named {{A_UPPER_CASE}} and I add it to the admin groups, I can see the same group in both columns:

 !image-2016-06-21-17-22-20-767.png|thumbnail! 

Admin rights are granted correctly, though.

Interestingly, when I remove that group from FeCru, it stays as an admin group (disappears from the non-admin list):

 !image-2016-06-21-17-27-46-295.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Admin groups that contain upper-case letters are not filtered out from the non-admin column

fields.description:
When having FeCru with < 4.0 configured with remote user directory (Crowd/Jira) with forced lowercase username and then upgrading to FeCru 4.0 users with mixed case user names will loose their avatars.

In details:

Let's take “John" example.

Pre 4.0

We have Crowd directory with forced lower case turned on and a user with “John” username.
In cru_user we have “john” user and his avatar is saved under hash(“john”).

In 4.0

“john” is still present in cru_user with the user name lowercased, in cwd_user we keep both username “John” / lowercase userame “john”

The avatar is expected to be found in hash(fecruUser.getUsername) where the username is taken from cwd_user so it is hash(“John”) and can’t be found.
fields.summary: After upgrading to 4.0 user avatar can be lost

fields.description:
It would be useful to be able to create foreign-language translations of the FishEye's interface so that it can be localised for non-English speakers in the same way as the other Atlassian products (JIRA, Confluence, Bitbucket etc.) can.

Now that FishEye has reached version 4.x it's been through two major re-architecture iterations; surely internationalisation is something which has now been considered as a capability?
fields.summary: Ability to translate interface into multiple languages

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
 # Open Global Permissions page, fisheye-users group is shown as "FishEye user" and crucible-users is shown as "FishEye & Crucible user".
 # Remove FishEye license key, on the Global Permissions page it shows fisheye-users as "None" and crucible-users as "Crucible user".
 # Click on fisheye-users "None" drop-down and select "None" again. (Probably an update is performed under the hood, despite value is the same).
 # Restore FishEye license key.
 # Open Global Permissions page, the fisheye-users group has been deleted.

 

Another way to achieve a similar result without toggling licences:
 # Open Global Permissions page, change fisheye-users group to "None". Group is still visible on the list.
 # Reload Global Permission page, the fisheye-users group disappears.

 

It seems that whenever any group is "None" and has not "Can add repository" permission enabled, then such row is being deleted automatically (as it has no effect). However this is not reflected in the UI immediately. 
Note this affects UX only, no impact on effective permissions so no security risk identified.

Possible fixes:

1. remove such row immediately (although then user would have no chance to follow the flow "change to None, enable can add repo toggle")

2. grey out the entire row indicating that it has no effect, give a hint that it will be removed

3. keep the row. user would have to click the delete icon (x) explicitly. 

also regarding the problem with switching license keys:

4. If user selects the same value from a drop-down, then do not update the value under the hood (as the "None" may mean either "None" for FECRU or "Fisheye" for CRU instance; similarly "FishEye" may mean "FishEye" for FECRU or "FishEye and Crucible" for FE instance).
fields.summary: Ineffective Groups on the Global Permissions page are removed in some scenarios

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
For users managed in external directories (e.g. Ldap, Crowd, JIRA), FishEye shows a "Change Password", a "Rename" and a "Delete" button.
!FE6571_UserOptions.png|width=500px!

h4. Deleting users
Since it is not possible to remove users managed in external directories, the following message is presented to the users in the FishEye user interface:
{noformat}
Error deleting user. Not allowed to delete user '<user_name>' from directory '<directory name>'. Please check the system logs for details.
{noformat}

The following can be found in the {{atlassian-fisheye-YYYY-MM-DD.log}} file:
{noformat}
2016-06-16 15:36:25,257 WARN  [qtp1680503330-2061 ] fisheye BaseAdminAction-addActionErrorAndLogWarning - Error deleting user.
com.atlassian.crucible.spi.services.NotPermittedException: Error removing user from directory
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager.deleteUser(DefaultUserManager.java:1263) [fisheye.jar:?]
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager.deleteUserAndRemoveCommitterMappings(DefaultUserManager.java:1238) [fisheye.jar:?]
...
Caused by: com.atlassian.crowd.exception.OperationNotPermittedException: com.atlassian.crowd.exception.ApplicationPermissionException: Not allowed to delete user '<user_name>' from directory '<directory name>'.
	at com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.core.CrowdServiceImpl.removeUser(CrowdServiceImpl.java:506) [embedded-crowd-core-2.8.5-m1.jar:?]
...
Caused by: com.atlassian.crowd.exception.ApplicationPermissionException: Not allowed to delete user '<user_name>' from directory '<directory name>'.
	at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric.removeUser(ApplicationServiceGeneric.java:817) [crowd-core-2.8.5-m1.jar:?]
{noformat}

h4. Changing passwords
The following appears when changing passwords:
{noformat}
The user could not be updated. Not allowed to update user '<user_name>' in directory '<directory name>'. Please check the system logs for details.
{noformat}

h4. Renaming users
The following appears when renaming users:
{noformat}
The user could not be updated. Cannot rename user '<user_name>' because directory '<directory name>' does not allow updates. Please check the system logs for details.
{noformat}

h3. Suggested Solution
Remove the option to "Change Password", "Rename" and "Delete" a user from an external directory.
fields.summary: As an admin, I don't want the "Change Password", "Rename" and "Delete" buttons to be available on users managed by external directories

fields.description:
Group normalisation from 4.0 upgrade tasks is breaking permissions. Scenario:
* backup created for 3.1.7 instance, repo "repo-uppercase-access" configured with "GROUP-A" can read access
* backup file restored on 4.1 instance, I can see following messages in the upgrade log
{code}$ grep -i renam /tmp/restore.out
INFO  - The group Global-Group-A has a duplicate name. Will rename the group to Global-Group-A_migration1
INFO  - The group Group-A has a duplicate name. Will rename the group to Group-A_migration1
INFO  - The group GROUP-A has a duplicate name. Will rename the group to GROUP-A_migration2{code}
on 4.1 instance repository "repo-uppercase-access" is configured so "GROUP-A" can read.  There should be "GROUP-A_migration2" instead

h3. Workaround
To address this problem, please refer to the [FishEye 4.0 group name normalization|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/FishEye+4.0+group+name+normalization] page for instructions.
fields.summary: group normalisation from 4.0 upgrade tasks is breaking permissions

fields.description:
h3. Summary
In FishEye, if you create a repository using the REST API, and you upload a private key, the repository creates successfully, but the UI in FishEye shows {{Private key has been generated by FishEye}} rather than {{Private key has been uploaded}}.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a repository using the REST API using private key authentication. 
# View the repository in the UI. Under {{SCM Details}}, it will show that {{Private key has been generated by FishEye}}.

h3. Expected Results
The UI should show {{Private key has been uploaded.}}
fields.summary: "Private key has been generated by FishEye" Shown When Creating Repository From REST API When Key is Uploaded

fields.description:
Because of this problem in https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-6634, the first attempt to upload a patch bigger than 800 files is not a problem because the bug doesn't constraint on a new revision, however upon adding another patch subsequently should fail. However, the UI shows that it hangs with a spinning wheel - while the debug logging shows this trace

{noformat}
2016-06-09 09:55:49,296 ERROR [qtp597307515-245 ] fisheye AddPatchAction$1-doInTransaction - Error adding patch
com.atlassian.crucible.spi.services.ReviewContentTooLargeException: Attempt to add too many revisions to a review - no more than 800 file revisions are allowed.
	at com.cenqua.crucible.model.Review.checkRoomForMoreContentExists(Review.java:1372) [fisheye.jar:?]
{noformat}

!screenshot.png|thumbnail!

Eitherway, the second patch will not get uploaded even after reloading the page
fields.summary: Uploading a patch after exceeding the max file revisions limit doesn't seem to respond on the UI

fields.description:
There are apparently no docs related to new user directories in fecru since 4.x other than [the user migration task|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/FishEye+4.0+user+directories+migration].
There should be something similar to [Bitbucket Server's LDAP integration guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Connecting+Bitbucket+Server+to+an+existing+LDAP+directory] for fecru too.
The only available guide is [outdated|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE037/LDAP+authentication].
fields.summary: Add/Update LDAP integration docs to reflect the new LDAP integration screens since embedded crowd

fields.description:
I can reproduce the problem on current FeCru snapshot "Version:4.1.0 Build:r46cc254 2016-06-06" as well, seems like a FishEye bug.

Just made 2 commits on a the test https://stash.atlassian.com/projects/TP/repos/fecru-test-sandbox/browse repository:
{code}

commit be188ff602d611f8d7d2e9f1ea149a46b8228eb8
Author: Piotr Święcicki <pswiecicki@atlassian.com>

    FECRU-2547 and another change

commit 6539aa4992b5a1a0d2ac0a98c0447bcbda493b50

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, when trying to add external users (e.g. coming from JIRA), to local groups, the UI displays the following message, which is not very informative:
{noformat}Failed updating group membership. Did not have update groups permission in any of the directories []
{noformat}
!adduser.png|thumbnail!
h3. Suggested Solution

The message could be improved, clarifying it's actually not possible to add external users to local groups. As stated at [https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Connecting+to+JIRA+for+user+management], users and groups coming from JIRA are read-only, so they can only be modified in JIRA.
{quote}The users, groups and memberships in this directory are retrieved from the JIRA server that is acting as user manager. They can only be modified via that JIRA server.
{quote}
 
h3. Workaround
 * Add the required groups (e.g. fisheye-users and crucible-users) directly in JIRA.
 * Alternatively, update the [Global permissions|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Global+permissions] to allow access to FishEye/Crucible to the required groups defined in JIRA
fields.summary: Improve error message when trying to add external users to local groups

fields.description:
As reported on FE-3577, there might be authentication issues when you have 2 users accessing the same SVN server containing 2 different repositories each with different authentication details, where the user for 1 cannot access the path of the other and vice-versa.

On the same issue there is documented confirmed workaround, to specify the username as part of the URL when defining your repository location.

FishEye could perhaps append username automatically to the URL to avoid this problem.  

There is also a chance the issue has been improved in the newer versions of svnkit, let's try to replicate again and see if it requires any more action.
fields.summary: ensure correct authentication is used for different repositories hosted on the same svn server

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
FishEye currently does not support NTLM authentication for outbound proxies.
This prevents FishEye to be allowed to access the Atlassian Marketplace to download the add-ons or an update of the application.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide the possibility to support NTLM authentication.
 
h3. Workaround 
Bypass the proxy for the access to the internet from the server hosting FishEye.

{noformat}

fields.description:
Apache Subversion introduced new FSFS repository format:
* https://subversion.apache.org/docs/release-notes/1.9.html

We've noticed performance degradation (about two times slower) when a repository is updated to the latest format and the bundled SVNKit via file:// protocol is used. Calling 'svnadmin pack' does not improve the situation.

Issue reported to TMateSoft:https://issues.tmatesoft.com/issue/SVNKIT-667
fields.summary: Performance degradation with SVNKit 1.9 and SVN 1.9 repository (FSFS format 7)

fields.description:
h3. Summary
After re-creating an Application Link between FishEye and Bitbucket, considering the Bitbucket URL have been changed, the repos previously added from Bitbucket into FishEye don't have their URL updated according to the new Application Link.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Link FishEye to Bitbucket.
# Add a repository from Bitbucket into FishEye, through the "FishEye Administration > Repositories > Bitbucket repositories tab".
# Change Bitbucket's Base URL.
# Re-create the Application Link.

h3. Expected Results
* Repositories previously added from Bitbucket will have their URL updated according to the new Application Link.

h3. Actual Results
* The URL in the repos remains the same.

h3.Workaround
Manually edit your repository, replacing the old URL by the new one. After doing this and restarting the repository, the repository will be properly listed as "Added" under the Bitbucket repositories tab.
fields.summary: Repository URL isn't updated when Application Link to Bitbucket is re-created

fields.description:
If an user creates a Subversion revision that is the addition of a new directory that also contains a binary file that has spaces in it's name, FishEye incorrectly considers it as a text file even if the mime-type is set correctly. This causes FishEye to display the binary content for the file instead of a download link and also causes significant performance problems if a Crucible review contains the file. There is no way to force the file to be considered as a binary file (because it already has the correct mime-type set.) FishEye performance also seems to degrade very quickly when indexing a repository that contains large numbers of these incorrectly identified binary files.

[^file-spaces.svn-dump.gz] file contains a SVN repository dump which demonstrates the problem. Files with " - Copy" are rendered as a garbage.

*Workaround*

This is a partial workaround for existing code reviews. It updates the 'is binary' flag for file revisions currently added to a code review. It does not fix the 'is binary' flag in indexed repositories, so adding a binary file to a new review will display it incorrectly again.

(!) Always back up your database before performing any modification to the database. If possible, try your modifications on a test server.
{code:java}
update cru_revision 
set cru_binary = true
where cru_revision_id in (
    select cru_revision_id from cru_revision, cru_stored_path
    where cru_revision.cru_path = cru_stored_path.cru_path_id
        and cru_revision.cru_binary = false
        and cru_stored_path.cru_path like 'DEFINE FILE PATTERNS HERE'
)

{code}
fields.summary: FishEye incorrectly identifies Subversion binary files as text if the filename contains spaces

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Application links fail with "username cannot be null or empty" when trying to enable 'user impersonation through 2-Legged OAuth'. This is a result of an empty Execute as user. We throw this stack trace because we try to check the group membership of an empty user, since it isn't filled in.

h3. Environment

Jira 6.4.3, 7.0.10

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create application link with 2LO Authentication between JIRA and FishEye
# Leave "The servers have the same set of users and usernames" unchecked.
# Allow user impersonation through 2-Legged OAuth from FishEye > Incoming Authentication > OAuth

h3. Expected Results
This application link should be valid and the local instance will accept OAuth requests from the remote instance that do not have a user associated with them. Without an executing user these are essentially anonymous requests sent over a secure, trusted connection. These requests have no associated permissions and so cannot access information that is restricted by user permissions.
h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-fisheye.log file:
{noformat}
2016-05-11 09:13:46,265 ERROR [qtp2017797638-328 ] fisheye TotalityFilter-logExceptionDetails - Exception "username cannot be null or empty" (java.lang.IllegalArgumentException) while processing "/crucible/plugins/servlet/applinks/auth/conf/oauth/add-consumer-by-url/61b6191d-d412-3043-a96c-75b7bceaed1f" (Referer:"https://localhost:8446/crucible/plugins/servlet/applinks/auth/conf/oauth/add-consumer-by-url/61a6191d-d412-3043-a96c-75b7bceaed1f")
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: username cannot be null or empty
        at org.apache.commons.lang3.Validate.notEmpty(Validate.java:398) [commons-lang3-3.3.2.jar:3.3.2]
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.AbstractInternalDirectory.isUserDirectGroupMember(AbstractInternalDirectory.java:892) [crowd-persistence-2.8.5-m1.jar:?]
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory.isUserDirectGroupMember(DbCachingRemoteDirectory.java:787) [crowd-core-2.8.5-m1.jar:?]
        at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.directory.RemoteDirectorySearcher.isUserDirectGroupMember(RemoteDirectorySearcher.java:54) [crowd-core-2.8.5-m1.jar:?]
        at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.directory.RemoteDirectorySearcher.isUserNestedGroupMember(RemoteDirectorySearcher.java:105) [crowd-core-2.8.5-m1.jar:?]
        at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.directory.DirectoryManagerGeneric.isUserNestedGroupMember(DirectoryManagerGeneric.java:862) [crowd-core-2.8.5-m1.jar:?]
        at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor390.invoke(Unknown Source) [?:?]
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) [?:1.8.0_66]
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:497) [?:1.8.0_66]

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Commit messages that contain Umlauts are being displayed incorrectly in FishEye, within the Activity Stream and in the *Activity* tab for the commit on the repository page.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

The problem occurs when initially adding the repository with a wrong encoding. Every change afterwards only changes the encoding of the file contents but not the commit messages.

h3. Expected Results

Commit messages display the Umlauts correctly. 

h3. Actual Results

Random ASCII characters are displayed instead of the desired Umlauts.

h3.Workaround

Re-add the repository with the correct encoding setting in FishEye.
fields.summary: Umlauts are displayed incorrectly in commit messages in CVS repositories

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, when performing a commit, being the committer's mail address the same as the mail address of two different FishEye users, FishEye is unable to determine the author of the commit. This directly impacts smart commits, as they do not work if the author isn't identified.

When the author isn't identified and the smart commit fails, the following is logged:
{noformat}
2016-05-13 11:00:00,000 WARN  [CommitNotifier1 ] com.atlassian.fecru.plugin.commithook.jira.JIRACommitHook JIRACommitHook-processHook - Unable to determine author for changeset 7dd16f1ae63d3934f6c96d4535632656601abf54 in repository gitRepo - no JIRA actioning will occur
{noformat}

h3. Suggested Solution
FishEye may fail to determine the author of the commit if there are two FishEye users with the same email address, therefore I suggest that, when FishEye identifies the committer mail address as being the same for more than one FishEye user, a specific WARN shows up in the logs, identifying the involved users.

h3.Diagnosis for identifying duplicated mail addresses
As a diagnosis step, the following query can be run in the database to identify if there are multiple users with the same mail address:
{code:sql}
SELECT u1.user_name, u1.email_address, u2.user_name, u2.email_address
FROM cwd_user u1 
	INNER JOIN cwd_user u2 ON u2.lower_email_address = u1.lower_email_address AND u2.lower_user_name != u1.lower_user_name
{code}
 
h3. Workaround 
If you identify more than one user with a single mail address, you can either:
* Edit your users, leaving the committer's mail address configured in the user you wish the commit to be mapped to.
* Manually adding a user mapping between the committer and the correct FishEye user at {{FishEye Administration > User mappings}}.
fields.summary: Log a WARN when committer matches two users with the same mail address

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When an SVN commit message that references a JIRA issue is changed to reference a different JIRA issue, and the change is indexed by FishEye/Crucible, the original JIRA issue displays the erroneous message "You don't have access to view all related commits. Please contact your administrator":
!devpanel1.png|thumbnail!
In addition, the Development Panel summary (the "x commits" message under the Dev Panel) for the issue which is now referenced by the commit message isn't updated.

h3. Environment
* JIRA 6.4.5
* FishEye 3.10.2
** Linked to JIRA through Application Link (method: OAuth w/ 2-LO). OAuth tokens created in both sides.
** Having a SVN repository indexed.
* svn, version 1.7.20

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# In JIRA, create two issues - let's name them TST-1 and TST-2.
# Perform a commit on the SVN repo, referencing TST-1. Wait for it to be indexed by FishEye, and confirm the Dev Panel summary is updated, showing *1 commit*, and that opening its details lists the commit.
# On the SVN repository, change the commit message to reference TST-2:
{noformat}
svn propset -r N --revprop svn:log "TST-2 testing change on N" URL
{noformat}
#* *N* must be replaced by the revision number for which you are editing the commit message.
#* *URL* must be replaced by the repo's location. It's not necessary to use this parameter if you are already in the repository in the command line.
# Go to {{FishEye Administration > Repositories}}, open the repo's config, then go to *Maintenance*. On this screen, under *Subversion Non-Versioned Properties (revprops)*, fill the fields *from* and *to* with an interval of revisions comprehending the one you changed, then click in *Start*.
# Confirm the commit message is updated by looking at this repo's activity in FishEye.
# Acccess the TST-1 issue in JIRA, then click in the *x commit", which won't be updated. You won't see the revision previously linked to this issue, and the message "You don't have access to view all related commits. Please contact your administrator" will be displayed, similarly to:
#* !devpanel1.png|thumbnail!

h3. Expected Results
* After the non-versioned properties of the revision are re-indexed, the Development Panel should be updated to reflect the commits that are actually linked to each issue.

h3. Actual Results
* The Development Panel isn't properly updated, displaying wrong results:
** For TST-1, it will keep showing the "x commits" link, but its content will be the erroneous message "You don't have access to view all related commits. Please contact your administrator".
** For TST-2, the Development Panel summary isn't updated, so there will be no "x commits" link, if this issue didn't have any commit previously linked to it.
 
h3. Notes
* This seems to be strictly related to the Development Panel, since the *Source* tab properly displays the new information right away.

*What DOES NOT help*
* Refreshing FishEye/Crucible caches at {{JIRA Administration > Add-ons > FishEye Configuration}} (I believe this is because these caches are for the JIRA FishEye Plugin, while the Development Panel is managed by the Development Integration Plugin).
* Restarting JIRA.
* Re-creating the application link.

h3.Workaround
I couldn't find a proper workaround around for this, but I observed that:
* After 30 minutes, when JIRA runs the job to collect new information from FishEye, the data in the Development Panel is properly adjusted (both the summary and the details).
* Sometimes, committing a new change seems to clean the Development Panel details - i.e. the number of commits displayed in the summary is still wrong, but the wrong message isn't displayed anymore when opening the Dev Panel. This seems to be intermittent.
fields.summary: Wrong message displayed on Development Panel when a commit message is updated in a SVN repository

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When synchronizing with a Crowd user directory (or a JIRA user directory), all users regardless of group affiliation are pulled into FishEye. Even users not allowed to authenticate in remote Crowd will still be migrated, FishEye/Crucible won't be able to distinguish them from "standard" users - they would still occupy licence slots, others would be able to pick them as reviewers etc.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # In Crowd: Add an "Application" called "fisheye". (Leave "Allow all users to authenticate" unchecked)
 # In Crowd: Add a Group called "fisheye-users".
 !Crowd - Application - FishEye - Groups.jpg|thumbnail!
 # In {{Crowd Administration >> Applications >> FishEye >> Groups}}: Add the group "fisheye-users".
 !Crowd - Users - not-fecru1 - Groups.jpg|thumbnail!
 # In Crowd: Add a user called "not-fecru1" with no group affiliation.
 # In FishEye: Synchronize user directory with Crowd.
 !FishEye - Users.jpg|thumbnail!
 # In FishEye: Go to {{Administration >> Users}}.

h3. Notes
 - This needs to be fixed on Crowd side – see CWD-1263
 - The users not belonging to a group who can access FishEye/Crucible will have a lozenge saying "NO ACCESS" next to their user name.
 - Both in Crowd and JIRA directory cases all users will be synchronized and they might occupy license slots if they end up with effectively granted global permission (either assigned individually or through group membership). That said, as there is no "Allow all users to authenticate" flag in JIRA, that is expected for JIRA-originating users, but might be surprising for Crowd, where one could expect only a subset of users to be synchronized
 - Due to CWD-3025 there is currently no way to assign a Crowd-originating user to local FeCru group

h3. Workarounds
 * Create dedicated group(s) in Crowd, add only selected users to the group(s) and grant login access only to those groups via FeCru global permissions. This requires one to have admin access to Crowd.
 * Assign users' login access rights individually via FeCru global permissions.
fields.summary: Crowd users not allowed to authenticate are pulled in as normal users

fields.description:
Backup fails with the error below when using SQL Server 2008 or newer database configured as SQL Server 2005 database. The error is:

{quote}Backing up sql...
1 rows written, 0 of 76 tables completed.
422 rows written, 1 of 76 tables completed.
425 rows written, 3 of 76 tables completed.
426 rows written, 3 of 76 tables completed.
432 rows written, 4 of 76 tables completed.
Error reading database: Cannot encode value for unsupported column type: "datetime" (93) of column .created_date
Backup failed{quote}

As explained in [Migrating to SQL Server|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crucible/migrating-to-sql-server-298977508.html] SQL Server type needs to be specified when setting up database. [SQL Server 2005 support was dropped|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/supported-platforms-298976955.html] in FishEye/Crucible 3.3 and it will be removed in future versions completely (CRUC-7712).

h3. No workaround
As the SQL Server 2005 and SQL Server 2008+ schema versions differ, there is no easy fix for the problem yet. Changing SQL Server type in Crucible database settings won't help.

h3. Fix
We fixed the issue and will release in the next point release. This will restore the backup capability.

h3. Updating schema
4.0.4 release will workaround the problem of DB using old schema. If you want to update your schema to use correct SQL Server 2012 types, follow these steps:
# Update to 4.0.4 (to be released very soon)
# Update DB setting from "Type=SQLServer 2005" to "Type=SQLServer 2012"; do not update the URL, so no migration will be triggered (click 'Save', not 'Save & Migrate').
# Perform backup
# Restore backup

The restored backup will set up the correct schema for SQL Server 2012.
fields.summary: Backup of misconfigured SQL Server DB fails due to unknown type "datetime" (93)

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Java 8 update 20 has introduced an additional flag for the G1 garbage collector that enables string deduplication to lower the memory footprint of the JVM. The functionality can be enabled by adding the {{-XX:+UseStringDeduplication}} JVM flag.

More information about this parameter can be found in the following links:
- [https://blogs.oracle.com/java-platform-group/entry/g1_from_garbage_collector_to]
- [http://java-performance.info/java-string-deduplication/]
- [https://blog.codecentric.de/en/2014/08/string-deduplication-new-feature-java-8-update-20-2/]

h3. Suggested Solution
Evaluate adding this parameter by default, as it is said not to cause significant performance overhead, however it can save additional heap memory, asynchronously to GC cycles.
fields.summary: Enable string deduplication by default

fields.description:
Just run a number of searches on atlaseye instance and norticed there is a number of qtp threads still active after 20 minutes, trying to open next lucene indexes:
{noformat}
qtp1457263953-51515: BLOCKED (Waiting on java.lang.Object@2751725f held by 51643)
   com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.RepositoryHandle.acquireEngine(RepositoryHandle.java:485)
   com.atlassian.fecru.search.common.lucene.MultiIndexRepositorySearcher.openReader(MultiIndexRepositorySearcher.java:45)
   com.atlassian.fecru.search.common.lucene.MultiIndexRepositorySearcher.getSearcher(MultiIndexRepositorySearcher.java:32)
   com.atlassian.fecru.search.common.lucene.FishEyeQuickSearcher.search(FishEyeQuickSearcher.java:104)
   com.atlassian.fecru.search.common.api.QuickSearchServiceImpl.search(QuickSearchServiceImpl.java:43)
   com.atlassian.fisheye.quicksearch.action.QuickSearchAction.search(QuickSearchAction.java:283)
   com.atlassian.fisheye.quicksearch.action.QuickSearchAction.execute(QuickSearchAction.java:207)
   sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
   sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)
{noformat}

I can see 4 incremental pingers indexing large repositories at the moment.  Not sure what is cause and what is a symptom yet, but having those qtp threads not giving up early but trying to continue acquiring more and more repositories after 20m does not help instance recovering from this.

Perhaps we need a time budget for MultiIndexRepositorySearcher to only acquire as much repositories as we can in the given time period?  
perhaps we don't need to acquire handles at all for Lucene searches?
fields.summary: diff/content multi repository searches won't time out early

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When the only change in a string is the addition or removal of a whitespace (including blanks, tabs, etc) and the "Hide Insignificant Whitespace" option is selected, FishEye does not show the string as being modified.

This is the current behaviour when the "Show All Whitespace" option is selected:
!FE6514_ShowAllWhitespace.png|width=600px!

This is the current behaviour when the "Hide Insignificant Whitespace" option is selected:
!FE6514_HideInsignificantWhitespace.png|width=600px!

h3. Suggested Solution
Always consider a whitespace change in a string to be significant.
fields.summary: As a user, I want whitespace changes in strings always to be considered as significant

fields.description:
The Activity Stream shows the Repository Description instead of showing the Repository Name.
This repository was automatically imported by Crucible/Fisheye from Bitbucket Server i also wonder why the Description is automatically set To the creation date.
Also the repository in Bitbucket Server doesnt have a Description (I guess you cant even configure one) and the Project has an Empty Description.
So i wonder where Crucible/Fisheye gets that description from when i cant change it in Crucible/Fisheye and i cant access it anywhere else.
I already tried removing the Repository and readding it now the Description is set to the Date i added the Repository to Crucible/Fisheye.


TLDR;
I found i can set the Description in the "SCM Details" menu in Crucible/Fisheyes repository settings. But its confusing that it doesnt automatically set the Description to the project name. And even more confusing that the activity stream prints in format of "to the %s project" which clearly should show the project name instead of some date when it was added.
fields.summary: Activity Stream shows Repository Description instead of Name

fields.description:
Update the bundled version of java to a version >= 1.8u71 (1.8 update 71), which fixes many security issues (http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/topics/security/cpujan2016-2367955.html#AppendixJAVA).
Included in the security fixes is a fix for CVE-2016-0483 "An out-of-bounds write flaw was found in the JPEG image format decoder in the AWT component in OpenJDK. A specially crafted JPEG image could cause a Java application to crash or, possibly execute arbitrary code. An untrusted Java application or applet could use this flaw to bypass Java sandbox restrictions".


See also: https://blogs.oracle.com/security/entry/security_alert_cve_2016_0603: 8u73 or later is recommended
fields.summary: Update Java version bundled found in the installer to a version >= 1.8u71

fields.description:
Our Crucible server is running horribly slow. It's a beefy server that has 4 cores and 10G RAM and the DB is hosted on a separate SQL Server. Our repo is Git but we have one very large one - 12G and 137K non-linear changesets. After 3 days, it has only indexed ~50K changesets and according to Fisheye documentation, performance should be 100-200KB/s on an avg PC. I wonder if these lock errors are causing an issue. Also, note: initial index is set to 3 threads but we're unsure if repos are actually single threaded in which case having 3 threads assigned will not help. 

Please review our logs and let me know if there's an actual defect you need to resolve or if something else is going on.
fields.summary: Thread Locking issues on Crucible

fields.description:
When FishEye detects number of repositories that need to be indexed (number of repositories added around the same time, or instance being migrated to another box with no FishEye caches), each Initial Pinger thread may spend a long time (hours, days) indexing particular repository.  That leads to starvation of other repositories.

Although in the short term it seems sensible to keep Initial Pinger threads "sticky", to avoid context switching, perhaps FishEye could ignore this "stickiness" after some threshold (e.g. 1h) so other repositories would have a chance to get indexed too.
fields.summary: Long initial indexing may lead to repository starvation

fields.description:
Just found a FishEye/Crucible instance where avatar URL was set with excessive space in front in Admin / Avatars / url.  Rather than 'http://gravatar.com/avatar/' it was set to ' http://gravatar.com/avatar/' (notice space at the front).

Avatars were shown correct in the product, but were broken in Development Panel in JIRA.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Once an explicit value has been set for the Timezone setting in the [User Profile|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/changing-your-user-profile-298976815.html] area, it is not possible to reset it to its default value.

How to reproduce this behaviour:
# open the user settings, and set an explicit value for the timezone
# the {{cru_timezone}} column in the {{cru_user_profile}} table will be updated with the value set in the user interface
# open the user settings again, and set the default timezone (this is the first one in the list)
# the {{cru_timezone}} column will not be updated with an emtpy/null value, therefore the previously set timezone is still set
# when reopening the user interface, the previously set timezone is selected in the drop down

+Note+: for FishEye/Crucible < 4.x, the {{cru_timezone}} column can be found in the {{cru_user}} table

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide the ability to reset the Timezone setting to the default value.
fields.summary: As a user, I want to be able to reset the Timezone setting to its default value

fields.description:
When upgrading FishEye using the installer, some customers may want to switch the database type or even point to a new version of the database at the same time.

Sample scenarios: 
* From FishEye 3.10 with Oracle 11g to FishEye 4.0.3 with Oracle 12c.
* From FishEye 3.10 with Oracle 11g to FishEye 4.0.3 with Microsoft SQL Server 2012.

The installer should ask whether the database currently configured or a new database should be used.
fields.summary: Installer should have option to switch database type

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The documentation [Connecting to Crowd|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Connecting+to+Crowd#ConnectingtoCrowd-Singlesign-on(SSO)withCrowd] to configure SSO for FishEye contains the following suggestion to modify FishEye {{config.xml}} file to achieve it.

The example provided is:
{code:xml}
<config>
...
    <security>
    ...
        <ajp...
        <crowd sso-enabled="true"/>
        <custom...
    ...
    </security>
...
</config>
{code}
however placing {{<crowd sso-enabled="true"/>}} as the first element of the {{security}} tag throws a ConfigException during FishEye startup while trying to parse the file.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Open {{$FISHEYE_INST/config.xml}}
# Add the crowd configuration as the first element of the {{<security>}} tag:
{code:xml}
<security allow-anon="false" allow-cru-anon="false">
       <crowd sso-enabled="true"/>
       <built-in>
               <signup enabled="true"/>
       </built-in>
       <admins>
               <system-admins>
                       <group>confluence-users</group>
               </system-admins>
       </admins>
       <avatar><disabled/></avatar>
       <emailVisibility/>
   </security>
{code}
# Start FishEye

h3. Expected Results
FishEye starting normally with SSO enabled.

h3. Actual Results
FishEye does not start and the following is showed in {{$FISHEYE_INST/var/log/fisheye.out}}:
{noformat}
2016-04-20 18:34:08,209 ERROR - at line 124: Expected elements 'custom@http://www.cenqua.com/fisheye/config-1 admins@http://www.cenqua.com/fisheye/config-1 avatar@http://www.cenqua.com/fisheye/config-1 emailVisibility@http://www.cenqua.com/fisheye/config-1 rawPolicy@http://www.cenqua.com/fisheye/config-1 restApiKey@http://www.cenqua.com/fisheye/config-1' instead of 'built-in@http://www.cenqua.com/fisheye/config-1' here in element security@http://www.cenqua.com/fisheye/config-1
2016-04-20 18:34:08,210 ERROR - Problem with config file: Error parsing config file (see logs): /opt/fecru_data/config.xml
com.cenqua.fisheye.config.ConfigException: Error parsing config file (see logs): /opt/fecru_data/config.xml
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.config.RootConfig.load(RootConfig.java:190) [fisheye.jar:?]
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.ctl.Run.mainImpl(Run.java:112) [fisheye.jar:?]
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.ctl.Run.main(Run.java:56) [fisheye.jar:?]
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) [?:1.8.0_72]
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62) [?:1.8.0_72]
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) [?:1.8.0_72]
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498) [?:1.8.0_72]
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.FishEyeCtl.mainImpl(FishEyeCtl.java:101) [fisheyeboot.jar:?]
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.FishEyeCtl.main(FishEyeCtl.java:44) [fisheyeboot.jar:?]
{noformat}
 

h3.Workaround
Modify the {{config.xml}} configuration to look like the following:
{code:xml}
 <security allow-anon="false" allow-cru-anon="false">
        <!--crowd sso-enabled="true"/-->
        <built-in>
                <signup enabled="true"/>
        </built-in>
        <crowd sso-enabled="true"/>
        <admins>
                <system-admins>
                        <group>confluence-users</group>
                </system-admins>
        </admins>
        <avatar><disabled/></avatar>
        <emailVisibility/>
    </security>
{code}

Once the {{crowd}} tag is placed after the {{built-in}} tag FishEye is able to start properly and successfully use SSO.
fields.summary: Configure SSO in config.xml throws a ConfigException
createParentDirs shouldn't be called on branch creation changeset

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
{{FISHEYE_INST/lib}} is a place to hold custom DB drivers.
Redundant jars in that directory can cause unexpected behaviour, as they might override the libraries bundled with FishEye installation.

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be nice if rather than requesting customers to provide listing of that directory, we'd get this information for free in support zip.

We might consider listing all files in both {{FISHEYE_INST}} and {{FISHEYE_HOME}} just in case, but that needs more thought regarding data sensitivity and size of that dump. There already exists a mechanism checking file hashes, see if that's not enough.
fields.summary: As an admin, I want the Support Zip to contain the list of files in FISHEYE_INST/lib

fields.description:
h3. Summary
An incorrect time is displayed for users with default timezone in their user profile.   The global server timezone is ignored and GMT time is displayed instead.
This affects various areas of the application, including:
- the Activity stream of a repository

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create two users in FishEye 
## {{test_emptytimezone}} without an explicitly set timezone option in his user profile
## {{test_settimezone}} with an explicitly set timezone (equal to the default one) in his user profile
## These are the setting of the two users in FishEye in the {{cruuser}} table !FE6489_cruuser_table.png|width=200px!
# Check the time on the Activity stream for a specific repository (the times indicated match the commit/push times)
# !FE6489_ActivityStream_correct.png|width=500px!

h3. Expected Results
The time of the repository operations (e.g. a push) is the same for both users.
!FE6489_ActivityStream_correct.png|width=700px!

h3. Actual Results
The time of the repository operations (e.g. a push) is *not the same for both users* and is incorrect for the user without an explicitly set timezone ({{test_emptytimezone}}).
!FE6489_ActivityStream_incorrect.png|width=700px!

h3. Notes
The problem occurs in the following conditions:
- when upgrading to version 4.0. ((i) As part of the upgrade to version 4.0, the {{cru_timezone}} column has been moved from the {{cru_user}} table to the {{cru_user_profile}}.)
- when creating the users directly in FishEye >= 4.0


h3.Workaround
Explicitly set the timezone for the affected users.
*Using the FishEye/Crucible user interface*
Each user can set the Timezone option in his [User Profile|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/changing-your-user-profile-298976815.html] page.

*Updating the timezone using a SQL command*
(!) Always back up your database before performing any modification to the database. If possible, try your modifications on a test server.
# Identify the users to be updated{noformat}
SELECT * 
FROM cru_user_profile
WHERE cru_timezone is NULL OR  cru_timezone = '';
{noformat}
# Update them with the most common timezone for the users ('Australia/Sydney' in the example below)
{noformat}
UPDATE cru_user_profile
SET cru_timezone='Australia/Sydney'
WHERE cru_timezone is NULL OR  cru_timezone = '';
{noformat}
fields.summary: Incorrect time displayed for users with default timezone in their user profile

fields.description:
Attempted to upgrade Fisheye from version 3.9.0 to 4.0.3, which provides a better user management than before. After performing the upgrade however, Fisheye sets the LDAP generic as a default user directory which as a result users who previously logged at Fisheye 3.9 cannot longer login at the Fisheye 4.

That forces me to create another user directory (Internal with Delegated LDAP) and create users that had been created. But I wish I could have the ability to migrate those already created users to another user directory like JIRA does.

Another point to mention is when I create a user in Fisheye, I don't know which user directory it might fall and I don't have the power to map them between. In JIRA admins has the ability to mention which user directory that user falls into. I know this was mentioned on FE-6485, but I want to reiterate here as well. 

Please advise.

Thanks.
fields.summary: As FishEye Administrator, I need the ability to manage users based on user directories

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently there is no way to determine the user account source directory in {{Administration >> Users}}.  This can lead to confusion in the source of a user account if there are more than 1 user directories active.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add the source user directory to the Users list.

For Example: JIRA and Bitbucket Server currently have a "Directory" column in their Users list as shown in the screenshot below:
!FE6485_BitbucketServer_Directory.png|width=400px!
fields.summary: As an admin, I want the source user directory to be displayed in the Users list

fields.description:
External user directories are read-only in FishEye/Crucible, however if an admin clicks a user account in {{Administration >> Users}} they are provided an edit screen which implies that changes can be made to the accounts such as "Edit Groups" and "Change Password".  Because the external directories are read-only, any attempt to change anything results in a sometimes unfriendly and definitely misleading error message.

For external user accounts, the user account screen should be read-only with a message stating that this account is managed externally (preferably with the name of the source external directory).
fields.summary: FishEye/Crucible should not provide an edit screen for external user accounts

fields.description: Sometimes, you would like to only list all the related commits for a specific file based on an issue key which is specified in the commit message so that you can filter out commits which has no relation to that particular issue.
fields.summary: Create a filter searchable by JIRA issue key to list out commits related on a specific file

fields.description:
h3. Summary

LDAP users synced to FishEye & Crucible cannot login until they are manually added to the fisheye-users or crucible-users groups although auto-add is enabled.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

While logged in as anonymous Admins user 

Connect external LDAP directory to FishEye. Ensure that all other User directories are disabled Enable  Read Only with Local Groups and ensure that fisheye users crucible users is present in the Default Group Memberships field

Attempt to login with a user present in external LDAP and listed in the Users section of the GUI

Check Directory Configuration Summary to ensure that autoAddGroups has value fisheye users crucible users is present

Manually add user to fisheye users

Attempt to login again

h3. Expected Results

User should be able to login after external LDAP is connected to FishEye

h3. Actual Results

User can login only after admin manually adds the user to the fisheye user group
fields.summary: LDAP users are not auto added to user groups after LDAP is connected to FishEye

fields.description:
h3. Summary

LDAP users synced to FishEye & Crucible cannot login until they are manually added to the fisheye-users or crucible-users groups although auto-add is enabled.

Steps to Reproduce:

While logged in as anonymous Admins user -

Connect external LDAP directory to FishEye. Ensure that all other User directories are disabled. Enable  "Read Only, with Local Groups" and ensure that "fisheye-users,crucible-users" is present in the "Default Group Memberships" field.

Attempt to login with a user present in external LDAP and listed in the "Users" section of the GUI.

Check "Directory Configuration Summary" to ensure that "autoAddGroups" has value "fisheye-users|crucible-users" is present.

Manually add user to fisheye-users

Attempt to login again

h3. Expected Results:

User should be able to login after external LDAP is connected to FishEye.

h3. Actual Results:

User can login only after admin manually adds the user to the fisheye-user group.
fields.summary: LDAP users are not auto-added to user groups after sync

fields.description:
In the document [https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/jira-and-crowd-authentication-298976831.html] the current description of the *Auto-add* setting is:

bq. Select *Create a FishEye user on successful login* so that your JIRA users will be automatically added as a FishEye user when they first log in.

This leads to the impression that users from JIRA will be added only upon logging into FishEye, while they're actually synced just based on the groups the user selects to be synced from JIRA.
Furthermore, the second option on this setting, named *Users must be added to FishEye manually* gives the impression that no user will be synced into FishEye, and that every user must be added manually to be able to authenticate, just using JIRA as the authenticator. This is also wrong, since, regardless of how this setting is marked, all users on the selected groups will be synced into FishEye.

My suggestion is to adjust the description of this setting on the documentation, setting the right expectations to users using this feature.
fields.summary: Adjust description of the "Auto-add" setting when syncing users from JIRA

fields.description:

Clicking either in {{Visible to logged in users only}} or {{Hidden}} options reloads the page with a parameter value in the URL ({{userListVisibility=LOGGEDIN}} and {{userListVisibility=DISABLE}}, respectively), but when the page reloads {{Public}} still shows as selected.

fields.description:
h3.Summary

LDAP users synced to FishEye/Crucible cannot log in until they are manually added to the default fisheye-users/crucible-users groups although "auto-add" is defined Default Group Memberships.


h3.Steps to reproduce
1. Connect external LDAP directory to FishEye/Crucible. Enable "Read Only, with Local Groups" and ensure that {{fisheye-users,crucible-users}} is present in the "Default Group Memberships" field.

2. Check "Directory Configuration Summary" to ensure that {{"autoAddGroups": "fisheye-users|crucible-users"}} is present.

3. Attempt to login with a user present in external LDAP and listed in "Users" section of the GUI.

h3.Expected Results

You should be able to login.

h3.Actual Results

User cannot login.

h3.Workaround

In the Global Permissions settings configure desired access to FishEye and/or Crucible, based on the remote ldap group membership (i.e. configure it for remote LDAP groups rather than local groups).
Alternatively, manually add user to fisheye-users and attempt to login again.
fields.summary: LDAP users are not auto-added to user groups after login

fields.description:
h3. Summary
User groups with at least an upper case letter can be successfully added to a permission scheme, but are not displayed when viewing its details.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Edit a permission set of a Permission Scheme ("Abandon" in the screenshots)
!FE6471_editPermissionScheme.png|width=200px!
# Start typing the group name (you'll see every user group in the drop down, including the ones with upper case letters)
!FE6471_selectUserGroups.png|width=200px!
# Select a mix of user groups containing only lower case letters and upper case letters ("test_group", "testlowercase", "TestUpperCase" in the screenshot below)
!FE6471_selectedUserGroups.png|width=200px!
# Check the permission details in the overview, you'll see that every selected group is listed (all groups are lowercase)
!FE6471_checkPermissionScheme.png|width=200px!
# Open the details of the action

h3. Expected Results
All previously selected groups are displayed.

h3. Actual Results
The groups with at least one uppercase letter ("TestUpperCase" in the example) +are *not* displayed+.
!FE6471_checkActionDetails.png|width=200px!

h3. Notes
The groups are correctly stored in the database and associated to the permission scheme, see the {{cru_ps_group}} and {{cru_ps_id}} for reference.
Not all permission schemes are affected by this, in general the permissions are still applied as expected even for users belonging to groups with upper case letters with the exception mentioned on CRUC-7678.
This issue is caused by the case-insensitiveness introduced by the [FishEye 4.0 user directories|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/fisheye-4-0-user-directories-migration-815241247.html].

h3. Workaround
Recreate the groups with only lower case letters.
To restrict Permission Scheme and remove group [REST endpoint|https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/fecru.html#d1e964] can be used
fields.summary: User groups with upper case letters are not displayed when editing the "Permission Scheme" details

fields.description:
If the window is very wide (approx >1000 pixels), the source view "hides" the code.  Reducing the width of the window causes the code to reappear.

Here's a picture...

!fisheye370-wide-window-source-view-blank.jpg!

This issue is a bit different than FE-3043, FE-3557, and FE-3381.

I have 3 monitors attached to my laptop:
# left: 1600x1200
# middle: 1920x1200
# right - 1030x1280 - problem doesn't happen because monitor is narrow
* This problem occurs on the larger monitors.  The threshold width for triggering the hidden code differs depending based on the monitor.  The threshold also varies whether I've
* <click-maximize-window-widget>-<followed-with>-<click-restore-window-widget>
* or <click-drag-window-edge-shrink-grow>

Chrome version: 49.0.2623.112 m
FishEye: 3.7.0 20150127093303
Windows 7 64-bit
fields.summary: wide window view source broke FishEye 3.7.0  Chrome 49 Win 7x64

Crowd has fixed this for Crowd The Product by setting the {{com.sun.jndi.ldap.connect.pool.protocol}} system property (see [here|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/crowd/commits/98545344206df907c030cfbb4e5a93cf4ddf8b91]. Something we could do too potentially.
fields.summary: Verify we enable SSL connection pooling for LDAP servers

	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:497) [?:1.8.0_60]
	at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.trackingstatements.TrackingStatementFactory$1.handleInvocation(TrackingStatementFactory.java:25) [fisheye.jar:?]
	at com.google.common.reflect.AbstractInvocationHandler.invoke(AbstractInvocationHandler.java:87) [guava-18.0.jar:?]
	at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy901.executeUpdate(Unknown Source) [?:?]
	at com.atlassian.activeobjects.backup.SqlUtils.executeUpdate(SqlUtils.java:34) [?:?]
	... 25 more
{noformat}

This is potentially only related to the Oracle DB, where sequences are created immediately with tables. Threads taking part in the race are {{ThreadPool1}} and {{active-objects-init-compatibility-tenant-0}}.

*This affects not only migration, but also restore from a backup file.*

h1. Workaround

If this occurs, the non ActiveObjects data is migrated already, and FishEye is already switched to using the DB. The user can manually finish the migration, by stopping the instance, and copying over the AO_* tables if needed.
fields.summary: Active object race condition in DB migration/restore (potentially to Oracle only)

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Connecting to LDAP offers an option under Advanced Settings named *Secure SSL*. This is responsible for checking the hostname of the instance you're connecting to, against the hostname you've set in the certificate imported into the truststore.
When LDAP's hostname doesn't match the one in the cert, the user has the option to uncheck this option, so the hostname isn't verified and the connection is possible. This option isn't offered for the connection to a JIRA directory though.

h3. Suggested Solution
The suggestion is to add this option, as a checkbox, similar as we have for LDAP connection, to the JIRA directory configuration, so we can workaround errors such as:
{noformat}
2016-03-24 14:00:00,000 ERROR [schedulerServiceQuartzScheduler_Worker-5 ] com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingDirectoryPoller DbCachingDirectoryPoller-pollChanges - Error occurred while refreshing the cache for directory [ 2 ].
com.atlassian.crowd.exception.OperationFailedException: javax.net.ssl.SSLPeerUnverifiedException: Host name 'jira.example.atlassian.com' does not match the certificate subject provided by the peer (CN=*.atlassian.com, O=Atlassian, L=Austin, ST=Texas, C=US)
{noformat}
fields.summary: Add "Secure SSL" option under Advanced Settings on JIRA directory configuration

fields.description:
When authenticating requests, certain authentication attempts might cause the database connection not to be closed properly. Over time, this can lead to exhausting the connection pool and cause the application to become unresponsive.

One identified cases for this are requests using [user token|https://developer.atlassian.com/fecrudev/remote-api-reference/rest-api-guide/authenticating-rest-requests] logins.
fields.summary: Some failed login request might cause a connection leak

fields.description:
h3. Summary
A FishEye existing user (with both username and user email) matching the Perforce committer doesn't get linked automatically to a commit unless a "User Mapping" is created.

h3. Steps to reproduce
# Create a user in Perforce with the following details:{noformat}
User:   test5
Email:  test5@atlassian.com
{noformat}
# Create a user in FishEye with the same username and email address
# Connect to Perforce with the newly created user (test5)
# Checkout a file, modify it and submit it
# Wait for the file to be indexed in FishEye:
!FE6446_CommitDetails.png|width=400px!

h3. Expected Results
The user in FishEye is linked to the Perforce one.

h3. Actual Results
The user in FishEye is not linked to the Perforce one. When the user test5 is selected in the user interface, the following details are displayed (note that it appears that the user did not commit yet). This is a screenshot from the {{FISHEYE_URL/user/test5}} page:
!FE6446_UserDetails_BeforeMapping.png|width=400px! 

Also the {{FISHEYE_URL/users}} page does not show any commit:
!FE6446_UserCommits_AfterMapping.png|width=400px! 

h3. Workaround
If a "User Mapping" is created between the FishEye user and the Perforce one:
!FE6446_UserMappingCreation.png|width=400px!

The commit is linked to the user (the screenshot is from the {{FISHEYE_URL/user/test5}} page):
!FE6446_UserDetails_AfterMapping.png|width=400px!

*Note* that this behaviour does not change after the "User Mapping" is removed (even after a restart), and the FishEye user keeps the link with the Perforce user.
fields.summary: Perforce committers are not automatically linked to FishEye user names, an explicit "User Mapping" is required

fields.description:
After upgrading to FishEye 4.x, The LDAP error "javax.naming.directory.InvalidSearchFilterException: Unbalanced parenthesis; remaining name..." occurs.

The cause of this error is that FishEye 3.x allowed the *User Object Filter* to be specified without parentheses.  Embedded Crowd requires the value of *User Object Filter* to be contained within parentheses.

{code}2016-03-25 17:14:03,161 ERROR [qtp1342346098-355 ] fisheye DefaultUserManager-loginWithSanitizedUserName - Could not authenticate user "UserName"
com.cenqua.fisheye.user.AuthenticationException: com.atlassian.crowd.exception.runtime.OperationFailedException
...
Caused by: org.springframework.ldap.InvalidSearchFilterException: Unbalanced parenthesis; nested exception is javax.naming.directory.InvalidSearchFilterException: Unbalanced parenthesis; remaining name...{code}


*WorkAround:*
* Add parentheses to the value of *User Object Filter*.
fields.summary: LDAP "Unbalanced parenthesis" error after upgrade

fields.description: Because the repository cache size can grow very large on disk, and a complete re-index can be very time consuming for large repositories, having a "rolling start commit" which would allow revisions to drop out after a certain age, or only maintaining a set number of revisions (for example the last 1000 revs) would make disk usage more manageable.

fields.description:
h3. Problem definition
*1.* In order to create an application link between JIRA Cloud and Fisheye, FishEye must be accessible via either port 80 or 443.
The page [Link to server apps from Cloud|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/link-to-server-apps-from-cloud-744721656.html] point to the "FishEye instructions."

The target page ([Configuring the FishEye web server|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/configuring-the-fisheye-web-server-298976936.html]) is generic, and does not provide specific instructions on how to set up the link.

*2.* The list of [Restricted functions in JIRA Cloud applications|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AdminJIRACloud/Restricted+functions+in+JIRA+Cloud+applications] (in particular the user management one) could be added to the Application Link page in FishEye as well (it is currently mentioned on the [FishEye User management limitations and recommendations|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/user-management-limitations-and-recommendations-298976859.html#Usermanagementlimitationsandrecommendations-JIRACloudapplicationsnotsupported] page)

*3.* The page [Linking FishEye to JIRA|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/linking-fisheye-to-jira-394464293.html] and the [Linking Crucible to JIRA|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Linking+Crucible+to+JIRA] one contain a link to "Linking to server applications from your cloud instance" that is now redirecting to [The JIRA Cloud documentation has moved|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/ALLDOC/The+JIRA+Cloud+documentation+has+moved].

h3. Suggested resolution
*1.* Provide a dedicated page containing the instruction on how to setup FishEye so that it can be connected to a JIRA Cloud instance.

*2.* Provide the list of restricted functionalities when connecting to JIRA Cloud.

*3.* Update the link to a direct link for FishEye.
fields.summary: As as admin, I would like a page explaining how to setup FishEye/Crucible to connect to JIRA Cloud, so that I can create an application link faster
